questions.clue: For moving faster in swimming, this law of motion emphasizes the benefit of pushing water backward to move forward.
In baseball, this phenomenon explains why a spinning ball curves in flight.
This synthetic material, used in skiing, enhances speed by reducing friction between the ski and the snow.
In cycling, reducing this type of aerodynamic drag, created by turbulent vortexes behind the rider, can significantly improve speed.
During long-distance running, this energy system provides most of the athlete's energy after the first few minutes by breaking down carbohydrates and fats.
In J.K. Rowling's series, this boarding school is famous for its Quidditch tournaments.
This video game features a world where players can compete in Blitzball, an underwater sport.
This universal event in Marvel Comics gathers Earth's heroes and cosmic beings in a contest known as the Contest of Champions.
The Land of Oz in L. Frank Baum's novels hosts a forest sport known as Quadrangle—that's like baseball but decidedly stranger.
In this dystopian universe created by Orson Scott Card, a game called Battle Room trains future military leaders to fight insectoid enemies.
This Prime Minister gave the 'We shall fight on the beaches' speech, rallying his country during WWII; his name is also famous in a football club's home country.
At the height of the American Civil Rights Movement, he delivered the 'I Have a Dream' speech on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial; his initials are shared with a legendary Boston Celtics player.
In 1961, this President challenged the nation to 'Ask not what your country can do for you...'; he shares his last name with a famous PGA Tour golfer.
In 1987, this U.S. President famously urged, 'Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!' during a speech at the Berlin Wall; his first name matches a former MLB star known for his save record.

This British orator, known for his 'The Few' speech during the Battle of Britain, was also awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature; his first name is the same as a legendary NBA player known as 'The Big Dipper.'
This art movement is known for its lifelike depiction of scenes from ancient Greece and Rome, similar to how a coach might lay out plans for a perfect game.
This 19th-century movement emphasized intense emotion and nature, often depicted as dramatic as a last-minute game-winning goal.
This art style, featured in the Renaissance, focused on harmony and proportion, much like a well-executed sports play.
This movement known for its light, pastel colors and playful themes can be likened to the finesse of a gymnast’s routine.
This 'ism', characterized by a return to classical themes and motifs of the late 18th century, parallels the strategic tactics in chess where precision is key.
For communication and courtship, these colorful fish perform dance-like swimming rituals, not unlike synchronized swimmers.
In a display similar to a football huddle, meerkats often engage in a group grooming session to reinforce social bonds.
During breeding season, the red-legged partridge engages in a behavior akin to dribbling a ball, using gravel to attract mates.
Expert divers, these seabirds perform a behavior called 'synching', comparable to diving athletes coordinating their plunge.
Mimicking players in a basketball game, the lyrebird can replicate chainsaw sounds and other environmental noises to impress females.

final.clue: In 1980, this athlete famously refused a $250,000 public offer to turn professional, choosing instead to continue competing as an amateur and later adding 7 more Olympic gold medals to their collection in 1984.
